notes: On 10 June 2024, pro-Palestinian students rallied and formed an encampment at UCLA in Los Angeles - Westside (California) in solidarity with Palestine and to demand the university disclose and divest all ties with Israel. At first, students marched, abandoning their first encampment and forming another encampment near Moore Hall. Using shields, they pushed and shoved security guards into Moore Hall, while security guards responded by punching students. Students gathered with shields and placed chicken wire around this new encampment while police in riot gear started lining up around the encampment and started to push students back with their batons. Police started pulling and grabbing students and detained several students. Police also launched pepper bullets at demonstrators. About a dozen counter-demonstrators also gathered to show support for Israel. Police arrested 25 demonstrators, including 18 students. Pro-Palestinian students then marched and gathered outside of UCPD headquarters in support of the arrested students. Counter-demonstrators showing support for Israel also gathered outside of UCPD headquarters. source: Daily Bruin; Fox11 (Los Angeles); Left Coast Right Watch; Los Angeles Times; NBC4 Southern California; People's City Council-Los Angeles; Twitter
notes: On 30 April 2024, pro-Palestinian demonstrators continued their encampment at Dickson Plaza at UCLA in Los Angeles - Westside (California) to demand a 'Free Palestine' and that the university divest from companies affiliated with Israel, disclose all UCLA financial assets, abolish targeted policing of pro-Palestinian demonstrations, call for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza and an end to Israeli 'occupation and genocide,' and boycott Israeli universities in a campus demonstration after the arrest of student demonstrators at Columbia University in New York on 18 April and amid the Israel-Hamas war which began in October 2023. The encampment was organized by Students for Justice in Palestine and UC Divest Coalition. A group of pro-Israel counter-demonstrators gathered with a sign reading 'Hamas, free the hostages.' Shortly before midnight, around 100 pro-Israel counter-demonstrators wearing black outfits and white masks removed barriers separating the two demonstrations, attempted to tear down the encampment, and attacked the demonstrators, throwing fireworks, tear gas, and debris into the encampment, spraying chemicals at demonstrators, beating up a student journalist and an editor with the Daily Bruin, striking demonstrators with wooden slabs, and yelling anti-Palestinian and anti-African American slurs. At least one pro-Israel demonstrator also waved a flag reading 'Moshiach,' referring to a Jewish belief in a messianic figure who will arrive during the end-times. Pro-Palestine demonstrators fought to keep counter-demonstrators away from their barricades, with some using pepper spray. Fights between the two sides around the barrier of the encampment continued for three hours into the early morning before dozens of police arrived and separated the two sides. No demonstrators were arrested. The university reported 15 demonstrators were injured, while UC Divest said 25 demonstrators were taken to the hospital after the attack. The doors and walls of nearby Royce Hall were vandalized and spray painted overnight, including with graffiti saying 'Free Gaza'.

notes: On 8 November 2023, students involved in a pro-Israel fundraising and awareness event at Concordia University and a pro-Palestinian fundraising and awareness event brawled at the downtown campus in Montreal - Center East (Quebec). Pro-Palestinian and pro-Israel students first engaged in verbal arguments and then arguments escalated into punching, pushing and shoving. Police arrested a 22-year-old student after they allegedly assaulted a 54-year-old security guard who was trying to prevent the fighting during the altercation among several students. Two security guards and one student sustained minor injuries during the altercation. This event took place in the wake of renewed fighting between Israel and Hamas.

The demonstration took place in the wake of renewed fighting between Israel and Hamas. Officers did not arrest anyone at the event but later issued warrants for four demonstrators on charges of impeding traffic. All four turned themselves in that week.

On 2 November 2023, CUNY students held a pro-Palestinian march in New York - Manhattan (New York) to call for 'free Palestine' and to support Gaza residents, as well as to oppose U.S. aid to Israel. Demonstrators tried to take down posters with Israeli hostages held by Hamas, and had altercations with passers-by who protected the posters. Demonstrators and passer-byers threw water bottles at each other. Some demonstrators also tried to burn an Israeli flag, then kicked a man who tried to take away the flag multiple times. There was also a counter-demonstration held across the street in support of Israel. No injuries or arrests were reported.
